巴西前总统雅伊尔·博尔索纳罗 (Jair Bolsonaro) 周五因在去年充满争议的选举中的行为而被巴西联邦选举法院 (TSE) 禁止这位极右翼民族主义者在 2030 年之前担任公职，他的政治生涯陷入了困境。

2022 年 7 月，选举前，七名法官中的五名投票判定 68 岁的博尔索纳罗滥用权力和滥用媒体，当时他召集大使对巴西电子投票系统提出毫无根据的指控。

他们的决定标志着博尔索纳罗的惊人逆转，这位火热的民粹主义者在十月份的投票中以微弱优势输给了左翼竞争对手路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦。

许多巴西人指责博尔索纳罗发起了一场全国性的运动来推翻选举结果，最终导致1 月 8 日数千名支持者入侵巴西利亚政府大楼。

选举法院裁决的影响可能会波及整个巴西政治，将卢拉的主要敌人从2026年的竞争中剔除，并在巴西右翼的竞争领域中开辟空间。

审判中的多数意见由法官贝内迪托·贡萨尔维斯撰写，他表示博尔索纳罗利用与大使的会面“散布疑虑并煽动阴谋论”。两名倾向保守派的法官提出了异议。

博尔索纳罗的长期对手、现任 TSE 主席的大法官亚历山大·德莫赖斯 (Alexandre de Moraes) 加入了多数派，称博尔索纳罗在向大使发表的“激进”演讲中散布了“一系列谎言和欺诈性消息”。

卢拉的团队庆祝了这一结果。

司法部长弗拉维奥·迪诺（Flavio Dino）在推特上表示：“TSE 审判传达了一些重要信息：撒谎不是行使公共职能的合法工具，政治不受丛林法则管辖。” “民主已经克服了几十年来最严峻的压力测试。”

博尔索纳罗否认有不当行为，他的律师已承诺向最高法院提出上诉，消息人士称上诉不太可能成功。

周五，博尔索纳罗称这一决定是“背后捅刀子”，并表示他将继续努力推进巴西的右翼政治。然而，东京证交所的决定并不是博尔索纳罗麻烦的结束。他仍然面临多项刑事调查，这些调查可能会让他入狱。

博尔索纳罗去哪儿？

尽管博尔索纳罗自己在 2026 年击败卢拉的希望可能已经破灭，但他表示，他将支持妻子米歇尔作为候选人。她是一个政治新手，但却是一名公开的福音派基督徒，可以赢得对卢拉持警惕态度的宗教右翼人士的支持。

“‘我们的梦想比以往任何时候都更加生动，’”裁决后她在 Instagram 上写道。 “我听从您的指挥，我的船长。”

他还有可能卷土重来。卢拉于 2019 年入狱，当时他的腐败定罪被推翻。他现在是总统。

Arko Advice 的分析师表示，博尔索纳罗仍然享有很高的政治声望。

他们在给客户的一份报告中写道：“在贾尔·博尔索纳罗的力量下，右翼或中右翼仍然没有其他选择。” “因此，前总统仍然是卢拉总统的主要对手。”

博尔索纳罗是美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普的长期粉丝，他在任期间受到了国际社会的批评，包括他对亚马逊雨林的管理乏善可陈，对COVID-19限制采取自由放任的态度，以及对巴西选举制度的毫无证据的攻击。

TSE 的审判是巴西对该国一代人以来最痛苦的选举的影响进行更广泛清算的一部分。虽然博尔索纳罗面临选举法庭的审查，但他的许多曾经的盟友在国会对 1 月 8 日骚乱进行的调查中受到了议员的质询。

联合国安理会周五一致投票决定结束在马里长达十年的维和任务，此前西非国家军政府突然要求13,000 人的部队撤离——美国称此举是由俄罗斯瓦格纳雇佣军组织策划的。

这次被称为“马里稳定团”的行动结束之前，自马里于 2021 年与俄罗斯瓦格纳集团合作以来，多年来的紧张局势和政府限制一直阻碍维和空中和地面行动，该集团是上周末俄罗斯一场未遂武装叛变的幕后黑手。

联合国维和人员被认为在保护平民免受伊斯兰叛乱分子袭击方面发挥了至关重要的作用，这场叛乱已造成数千人死亡。一些专家担心，任务离开后，安全局势可能会恶化，导致装备不足的马里军队只剩下约 1000 名瓦格纳战士，去打击控制沙漠北部和中部大片领土的武装分子。

由 15 名成员组成的安理会通过了一项法国起草的决议，要求特派团于周六开始“停止行动、移交任务以及有序、安全地缩编和撤出人员，目标是完成这一任务”。流程将于 2023 年 12 月 31 日之前完成。”

在安理会投票时，白宫指责瓦格纳领导人叶夫根尼·普里戈任帮助策划联合国维和部队撤离马里，并表示有信息显示马里当局自 2021 年底以来已向瓦格纳支付了超过 2 亿美元。

白宫国家安全发言人约翰·柯比告诉记者：“不为人所知的是，普里戈任帮助策划了这次离职，以促进瓦格纳的利益。” “我们知道，马里高级官员直接与普里戈任员工合作，通知联合国秘书长，马里已撤销对马里稳定团任务的同意。”

马里政府发言人没有立即回应置评请求。

俄罗斯驻联合国副大使安娜·埃夫斯蒂涅娃告诉安理会，马里做出了“主权决定”。

她说：“我们谨确认我们对巴马科的支持，因为巴马科希望承担全部责任，并在稳定马里国家方面发挥主导作用。”俄罗斯将继续为马里在双边基础上实现该国局势正常化提供全面支持。”

'警惕的'

马里驻联合国大使伊萨·孔福鲁告诉安理会，马里政府注意到该决议的通过，并将“保持警惕，确保遵守”撤军时间表。

孔福鲁表示：“安理会继续将马里局势视为对国际和平与安全的威胁，政府对此感到遗憾。” “马里仍然愿意与所有希望与之合作的伙伴合作，但前提是尊重我们国家政策的指导原则。”

安理会决议授权马里稳定团“在其附近地区”应对平民迫在眉睫的暴力威胁，并在 9 月 30 日之前为由平民主导的安全运送人道主义援助做出贡献。

它要求联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯与马里当局合作制定一项移交马里稳定团任务的计划，并在8月15日之前提交给安理会。它呼吁马里在马里稳定团撤军期间与联合国充分合作。

孔福鲁周四表示，马里将与联合国密切合作。

两周前，马里外交部长阿卜杜拉耶·迪奥普在请求马里稳定团撤离时告诉安理会，联合国行动与马里当局之间存在“信任危机”。

截至 12 月 31 日，马里稳定团还被授权为联合国人员、设施、车队、装置和设备以及相关人员提供安全保障；执行营救处于危险中的联合国人员和人道主义工作人员并提供医疗后送的行动。

马里一直在努力遏制 2012 年起义后扎根的伊斯兰叛乱。安理会于 2013 年部署了马里稳定团，以支持外国和当地恢复稳定的努力。对日益严重的不安全局势的不满促使马里在 2020 年和 2021 年发生了两次政变。

巴西前总统雅伊尔·博尔索纳罗 (Jair Bolsonaro) 在 2026 年重新担任总统的希望可能落空。但这并不意味着三年后博尔索纳罗不会参选。

巴西联邦选举法院（TSE）周五冻结了博尔索纳罗的政治生涯，禁止这位极右民族主义者在 2030 年之前担任公职，因为他在去年的选举中散布了对该国投票制度的毫无根据的指控。

这项裁决对这位 68 岁的职业政治家来说是毁灭性的挫折，他直到最近还是巴西最有权势的人。

但这可能并不意味着博尔索纳罗家族的终结。

博尔索纳罗在抵达里约热内卢后不久于周四发表讲话，在那里他受到了“罪犯”和“政变分子”的喊叫，他支持他的妻子米歇尔2026年。

“当然，我会支持米歇尔竞选，”他说。

在 TSE 裁决后不久，米歇尔在 Instagram 上发帖写道：“‘我们的梦想比以往任何时候都更加鲜活’……我听从你的指挥，我的船长。”

博尔索纳罗还面临多项刑事调查，可能会让他入狱。许多巴西人指责博尔索纳罗去年在投票中输给左翼总统路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦后，引发了一场全国性的否认选举运动。

他此前曾表示，一旦“退出游戏”，他可能会成为政治上的造王者。但他的许多前盟友已经将 2026 年的希望寄托在圣保罗州长塔西西奥·弗雷塔斯和米纳斯吉拉斯州州长罗梅乌·泽马等新面孔上。

现在，他保持影响力的最佳机会可能在于他的家人。

米歇尔·博尔索纳罗是政坛新人，但她平易近人的举止和对传统价值观的重视赢得了巴西工人阶级女性的支持。在 2022 年竞选期间，她的知名度有所上升，随着博尔索纳罗努力吸引女性选民，她在博尔索纳罗的活动中变得越来越引人注目。她去年加入了保守的自由党，现在是该党妇女运动的领导人。

她不排除竞选公职的可能性。

“如果我走在这条道路上，并且我的心为此燃烧，我可以成为一名立法候选人，”她在五月说道。

41 岁的米歇尔和巴西 2 亿人口中大约三分之一的人一样，是一名福音派基督徒。福音派人士是博尔索纳罗保守家庭价值观的大力支持者，并对卢拉保持警惕。

福音派联邦上诉法院法官威廉·道格拉斯 (William Douglas) 是博尔索纳罗 2021 年最高法院候选人的候选人之一，他表示米歇尔对一些选民提出了上诉。

“当然，一些福音派女性会认同她，但我认为她会在前总统的选民中取得更大的成功，”他说。

她并不是唯一有机会担任巴西最高职位的博尔索纳罗。博尔索纳罗前夫所生的两个儿子都是联邦议员。他们可能怀有自己的总统野心，尽管两人都没有宣布参选。

42 岁的参议员弗拉维奥·博尔索纳罗 (Flavio Bolsonaro) 在其父亲任职四年期间是巴西利亚的关键幕后操纵者，负责在整个联邦官僚机构中任命盟友。但他在担任里约州议员期间仍然受到腐败指控的玷污，但他否认了这些指控。

38 岁的国会议员爱德华多·博尔索纳罗 (Eduardo Bolsonaro) 扮演了博尔索纳罗家族的外国特使的角色，出现在美国枪支展和保守派政治会议上，与史蒂夫·班农 (Steve Bannon) 等备受瞩目的右翼人士有过接触。但他仍然是一个两极分化的人物，政治观点边缘，支持有限。

Gabriel Stargardter 报道，Rosalba O'Brien 编辑; Fri, 30 Jun 2023 19:04:33 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/bolsonaro-eyes-2026-candidacy-his-wife-his-political-future-evaporates-2023-06-30/ https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/bolsonaro-eyes-2026-candidacy-his-wife-his-political-future-evaporates-2023-06-30/Gabriel Stargardter巴西博尔索纳罗/米歇尔（更新 2，PIX） Moms for Liberty emerges as a force in the 2024 U.S. presidential election

自由妈妈组织是一个保守的家长权利倡导组织，自两年多前成立以来迅速扩张，周五，随着 2024 年共和党总统提名的主要竞争对手在费城举行的全国会议上发表讲话，该组织展示了其政治力量。

佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯（Ron DeSantis）对酒店舞厅的人群说：“2024 年将是全国家长最终反击的一年。”他是领先者唐纳德·特朗普最接近的挑战者。

预计前总统特朗普将在当天晚些时候发表讲话。

他们与包括前南卡罗来纳州州长妮基·黑利在内的其他三名候选人的出现，证明了他们的竞选活动对明年提名竞赛中与教育相关的种族和基于性别的文化问题的重视程度。

这些文化战争问题激起了部分共和党选民的兴趣，共和党竞争对手希望吸引学龄儿童的父母，特别是郊区妇女，这是美国总统选举中的一个重要投票群体。

德桑蒂斯谈论了他在教育方面的记录，告诉群众他作为州长如何支持扩大该州私立学校学券计划的立法。他还为佛罗里达州公立学校书架上下架有关性和性别认同主题的书籍进行了辩护。

他说：“用美国纳税人的钱把这种垃圾带进我们的学校是根本错误的，也是没有立足之地的。”

海莉在讲话中谴责跨性别女孩参与学校体育运动，称其为“我们这个时代最大的女性问题之一”。

“他们实际上是在试图抹去我们所取得的所有进步，”她告诉人群中的女性。

酒店外，大约 300 名来自自由主义倡导团体的人抗议这一活动。

在周五的节目开始之前，LGBTQ 倡导组织 Agenda PAC 的活动人士在酒店房间的门上挂上了写着“请打扰。法西斯主义正在进行中”的衣架。

“自由妈妈”组织于 2021 年疫情最严重时期发起，在帮助选举当地学校董事会的保守派成员方面发挥着越来越积极的作用，同时还游说州立法机构采取措施，例如佛罗里达州禁止教授性别认同概念的法律给小学生和中学生。

共和党候选人对该组织成员的示好标志着该组织已成为国家政治中的主要保守派参与者。其峰会由传统基金会和培训公职候选人的领导力学院等长期右翼政策机构赞助。

该组织位于佛罗里达州的联合创始人蒂娜·德科维奇表示，该组织不会在初选中支持共和党候选人，而是坚持要求候选人承诺支持其推进政策的议程，以增加“家长参与”和“防御政府越权。”

“候选人知道，目前国内的头号问题是对父母权利的攻击和我们国家的教育失败，”德科维奇说。

追求妈妈们

没有哪个总统候选人比德桑蒂斯更努力地与该团体保持一致，他将限制跨性别权利和反对进步教育政策作为竞选的核心。

最近，在爱荷华州德桑蒂斯的总统竞选活动中，可以看到身穿印有该组织标志的志愿者在工作。

46 岁的克里·吉莱斯皮 (Kerry Gillespie) 表示，她一直在与马里兰州社区所谓的过度扩张的学校政策作斗争，她在周五的活动中表示，她在初选中支持德桑蒂斯。

“这个人必须超越口头承诺，并拥有可以看到他们成就的记录，”吉莱斯皮说。

其他共和党候选人也在讨好“自由妈妈”组织，该组织目前在 44 个州拥有 12 万名会员。

来自南卡罗来纳州的美国参议员蒂姆·斯科特最近在他的家乡赞助了该组织的筹款活动。今年五月，特朗普领导下的副总统迈克·彭斯（Mike Pence）因批评爱荷华州一个学区的“性别过渡”计划而被该组织的成员包围。

在监控仇恨团体的南方贫困法律中心将“自由妈妈”贴上“反政府极端主义”组织标签后，海莉公开为该组织辩护。

该组织的成员也出现在特朗普的集会上，穿着他们的签名衬衫。

艾伦·阿金 (Alan Arkin) 去世，享年 89 岁。艾伦·阿金 (Alan Arkin) 是一位多才多艺、多产的美国演员，曾在喜剧和戏剧角色中崭露头角，并因在 2006 年电影《阳光小美女》中扮演一位吸食海洛因的祖父而获得奥斯卡奖。

"Our father was a uniquely talented force of nature, both as an artist and a man. A loving husband, father, grand and great grandfather, he was adored and will be deeply missed," Arkin's sons Adam, Matthew and Anthony wrote in a joint statement.

Arkin died at his home in Carlsbad, California, on Thursday, Variety reported.

Arkin appeared in scores of films, was nominated for an Academy Award four times and won a Tony Award, Broadway's top honors, in 1963 for his first major stage role in Carl Reiner's "Enter Laughing."

His first major movie role also earned him an Oscar nomination - best actor for playing a Soviet sailor in the 1966 Cold War comedy "The Russians Are Coming! The Russians Are Coming!"

Arkin was initially turned down for the "Little Miss Sunshine" role that ultimately won him a best-supporting-actor Oscar because the directors thought he was too healthy. The character was a foul-mouthed 80-year-old grandfather who was frail and shaky from years of drug abuse and bad behavior.

"It's the best rejection I ever got in my life - they thought I was too virile," Arkin said, flexing his biceps and striking a muscleman pose during a 2007 interview with The New York Times.

Arkin delivered a memorable dramatic turn as a psychopathic killer in the 1967 film "Wait Until Dark," opposite Audrey Hepburn. He later said he hated the scenes in which his character terrorizes Hepburn, saying, "I didn't like being cruel to her. It made me very uncomfortable."

He appeared as a deaf-mute in the adaptation of Carson McCullers' novel "The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter" in 1968, drawing his second Academy Award nomination for best actor.

In 1970, he starred in the film version of Joseph Heller's novel "Catch-22," putting in a strong performance in a movie that was considered a disappointment.

He also won plaudits for his performance in the 2012 thriller "Argo," which told the true-life story of a CIA mission to free six Americans from Iran by disguising them as crew members of an elaborately concocted but fictitious film about aliens. Director Ben Affleck's film won the Academy Award for best picture.

Arkin remained active in film and television well into his 80s. He won praise and Emmy nominations for the TV series "The Kominsky Method," also starring Michael Douglas, that debuted in 2018.

"Did ANYONE have the range Alan Arkin had? Hilarious, sinister, insane, tragic. No mood he couldn't live in," tweeted actor and comedian Patton Oswalt.

Some of Arkin's other films included "The Seven-Per-Cent Solution" in 1976, "The In-Laws" in 1979, "Edward Scissorhands" in 1990, "Glengarry Glen Ross" in 1992, "Grosse Pointe Blank" in 1997, "The Slums of Beverly Hills" in 1998, "Get Smart" in 2008, "Sunshine Cleaning" in 2008, "Stand Up Guys" in 2012 and "Going in Style" in 2017.

Not all his movies fared well. For example, he said he did "Freebie and the Bean" in 1974 because "I needed the bread."

Alan Wolf Arkin was born on March 26, 1934, in the New York City borough of Brooklyn, but his family moved to Los Angeles when he was 11. His father, a painter and writer, lost his job as a teacher after he was accused of being a communist during the "Red Scare" of the 1950s.

Arkin was an original member of Chicago's influential improvisational comedy troupe Second City and sang in a folk group that had a hit version of the 1950s single "The Banana Boat Song," popularized by Harry Belafonte. Arkin also worked as a movie and stage director, made many TV appearances and wrote several books.

Arkin is survived by his wife Suzanne, his three sons, four grandchildren and a great-grandson.

Outside an apartment block scarred by the missile strike that struck a bustling restaurant in Ukraine's city of Kramatorsk this week, a mother sat still on Friday, resting a pale hand on the head of each of her two dead twin daughters.

Fourteen-year-olds Anna and Yuliia Aksenchenko were among 12 people who were killed when a Russian missile hit a pizza restaurant in the eastern city on Tuesday evening. They had been in the vicinity of the restaurant during the attack.

On Friday morning, the family held a mourning ceremony for them at their apartment several hundred metres away from the site.

The missile came hurtling out of the sky on a balmy summer evening, when the restaurant and its large outdoor terrace were packed with customers.

Three days later, the middle-aged mother of the twins looked completely drained of vitality as she sat by the graves of her daughters in a black leather jacket.

She sat motionless with one hand on each daughter for half an hour, her body slumped and her head bowed.

The woman could scarcely walk, as if incapacitated by her grief. She had to be supported when walking by the girls' father and another relative.

None of the family members were in any condition to speak to reporters, the girls' godfather said.

The girls lay in coffins with open caskets, but were covered with a glistening white and gold sheet.

Mourners said the girls had been dressed in wedding dresses for their burial, a custom in Ukraine for girls who die too young to marry.

Initially unable to find two wedding dresses in a city not far from the front and where wedding parlours are closed, friends and family issued an online appeal for well-wishers to donate two dresses so that the girls could be buried.

"This is a tradition. If girls become angels, go up to heaven before getting married, they are dressed in wedding dresses so they can find their other half there," said Viktoria Kushka, 50, a teacher who taught Anna and Yuliia in first grade.

Speaking in one of the classrooms at the nearby school where the girls studied, Kushka recalled her memories of the girls.

Some of the school's windows had been shattered by the strike.

"I remember them in first grade. They were two little sunshines. With fair hair, always (tied) with a big white ribbon, smiling, big light blue eyes. Always together, always supporting each other."

At the ceremony, a crowd of around 30 relatives, friends and local residents gathered to pay their respects.

He said Ukrainian intelligence and security forces had reported on the situation in Belarus, Ukraine's northern neighbour, at a meeting of top military and political leaders.

"The decision...is for Commander-in-Chief (General Valeriy) Zaluzhnyi and 'North' commander (General Serhiy) Naev to implement a set of measures to strengthen this direction," Zelenskiy said on the Telegram messaging app.

He did not mention Wagner Group boss Prigozhin in the brief post on Telegram.

"Right now, there is no direct threat of offensive actions from Belarus and Russia in the zone that is the responsibility of the Northern Group of Forces," Naev said.

But he said moves to strengthen Ukraine's defence capabilities were needed in the event of a growing threat, and added: "Our intelligence does not stop work to obtain information."

Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Maliar said earlier on Friday that Ukrainian troops were advancing in all directions of the counteroffensive they began against Russian forces this month.

"If we talk about the entire frontline, both east and south, we have seized the strategic initiative and are advancing in all directions," she told Ukrainian television.

An ancient Greek altar for family worship dating back more than 2,000 years has been found in the archaeological site of Segesta on the Italian island of Sicily, local authorities said on Friday.

Sicily's regional government said the altar was probably in use at the height of Hellenic cultural influence, just before the rise of the Roman empire in the first century before Christ (BC).

It had been buried for centuries by a few centimetres of earth and vegetation in the area of ​​the Southern Acropolis at the Segesta site, which is in the western part of the island.

"The Segesta site never ceases to amaze us," said Sicily's regional culture minister Francesco Paolo Scarpinato.

"Excavations continue to bring to light... pieces that add new perspectives and interpretations to a site where multiple civilizations are stratified," he said in a statement.

Segesta, renowned for its 5th-century-BC temple, was an ancient Greek city nestled between mountains.

Apart from the altar, archaeologists also dug out a similar-shaped relic that they believe may have been a support for a sculpture. Both finds are perfectly preserved, the regional government said.

The US Supreme Court's decision to strike down President Joe Biden's student debt relief would claw back more than $300 billion in costs associated with the program that were recognized last year, marking a major reduction in this year's deficit - at least on paper.

The court ruled 6-3 on Friday that Biden's unilateral decision to offer up to $10,000 to $20,000 in one-time student debt forgiveness to couples earning up to $250,000 had circumvented Congress' constitutional right to make laws on spending. The debt relief program had been blocked by the legal challenges that led to the Supreme Court's decision.

The Department of Education had estimated that the debt relief would cost taxpayers about $30 billion annually over the next decade through foregone loan repayments - about $2.5 billion per month - or about $305 billion in total. The Department estimated the net present value of the loan forgiveness at $379 billion over a decade.

The US Treasury last year took a $430 billion charge against fiscal 2022 budget results to cover these costs as well as an extension of the general COVID-19 moratorium on payments through the end of 2022. The move had the effect of limiting a dramatic reduction in the fiscal 2022 deficit to $1.375 trillion from $2.775 trillion the prior year.

Without the advance recognition, the deficit would have fallen below $1 trillion as COVID relief programs ended and revenues surged.

Marc Goldwein, senior policy director for the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget (CRFB), a fiscal watchdog group, estimated that about $320 billion of the pre-emptive costs would be reversed during fiscal 2023 after the Supreme Court ruling.

The Congressional Budget Office is forecasting an increased deficit of $1.539 trillion this year due to falling revenues and higher spending and healthcare costs. A reversal of more than $300 billion would make it appear that this year's fiscal deficit fell slightly from 2022.

"It's deficit reduction relative to a deficit increase that never really went into effect," Goldwein said. Biden "announced the policy and they weirdly recorded it as having increased the deficit before they implemented the policy in any meaningful way."

The smaller reversal relative to the $380 billion initial cost estimate is due to a recent expansion of income-driven repayment relief , which will cut undergraduate loan repayments by half for many borrowers and drop them to zero for those in a family of four earning less than $62,400.

Many borrowers who would have seen loans forgiven under Biden's plan will now benefit from the more generous income-driven repayment scheme instead, Goldwein said.

The cash flow impact of the Supreme Court ruling will be minimal, perhaps adding back about $2 billion in receipts per month that would have been lost had the forgiveness plan been upheld.

Shai Akabas, economic policy director at the Bipartisan Policy Center, said another reason the deficit reduction resulting from the ruling would be lower than the initial cost recognition was because the general student loan repayment moratorium was extended well into calendar 2023 by the Biden administration.

The debt ceiling legislation earlier this month prohibited any further extensions, and the Department of Education has said that repayments will resume in October. This will take hundreds of dollars a month out of millions of consumers' pockets and create new headwinds for the US economy, economists say.

  • Row shows deep party split over treatment of ex-PM Johnson

British international environment minister Zac Goldsmith resigned on Friday, saying Prime Minister Rishi Sunak was "uninterested" in environmental issues, in a move highlighting the deep split in the ruling Conservative Party.

With an election expected next year and the Conservative Party trailing in opinion polls, the party is split between those loyal to Sunak and those, like Goldsmith, who think former prime minister Boris Johnson has been unfairly sidelined.

Goldsmith said on Friday Britain had lost its global leadership role on climate issues. He rejected an attempt by Sunak to frame his resignation as a reaction to being asked to apologise for criticism of a parliamentary committee investigation into Johnson.

Goldsmith said he was happy to make an apology for his criticism of the Privileges Committee.

"The problem is not that the government is hostile to the environment, it is that you, our Prime Minister, are simply uninterested," said Goldsmith, who sits in parliament's upper chamber and held the title of Minister of State for Overseas Territories, Commonwealth, Energy, Climate and Environment.

Sunak replied to Goldsmith with a letter that began:

"You were asked to apologise for your comments about the Privileges Committee as we felt they were incompatible with your position as a Minister of the Crown. You have decided to take a different course."

Some of Johnson's allies have been increasingly critical of the government since he resigned from parliament earlier this month in protest over a report that found he had deliberately misled lawmakers about COVID lockdown parties.

Goldsmith was on Thursday reprimanded by a parliamentary committee which criticised the behaviour of a group of Johnson loyalists for seeking to intimidate the panel that criticised his conduct during lockdown.

GLOBAL CLIMATE LEADER?

In his resignation letter, Goldsmith said Britain had "visibly stepped off the world stage and withdrawn our leadership on climate and nature".

That echoed a report published earlier this week by the government's climate advisers, who said Britain had lost its position as a global leader on climate action and was not doing enough to meet its mid-century net zero target.

The Climate Change Committee report also highlighted a recent decision to commission a new coal mine and support for new British oil and gas production.

Sunak responded to Goldsmith by saying: "We can be proud of the UK's record as a world leader on net zero. We are going far beyond other countries and delivering tangible progress."

When Sunak was serving as finance minister, Britain won international plaudits in 2021 for brokering a global climate pact at the COP26 summit in Glasgow. However shortly after becoming prime minister, Sunak said he would not attend the 2022 COP summit, before changing his mind when faced with criticism.

Nevertheless, Sunak has set up a new government department in charge of Britain's net zero plan and highlighted the importance of growth in green industries to Britain's economic future.
